text.paragraph: No data available for this section

Joint Pain
Joint pain (arthralgia) may be caused by many things. Joint pain is likely to go away when you follow instructions from your health care provider for relieving pain at home. However, joint pain can also be caused by conditions that require more treatment. Common causes of joint pain include:
Bruising in the area of the joint.
Injury caused by repeating certain movements too many times (overuse injury).
Age-related joint wear and tear (osteoarthritis).
Buildup of uric acid crystals in the joint (gout).
Inflammation of the joint (rheumatic disease).
Various other forms of arthritis.
Infections of the joint (septic arthritis) or of the bone (osteomyelitis).
Your health care provider may recommend that you take pain medicine or wear a supportive device like an elastic bandage, sling, or splint. If your joint pain continues, you may need lab or imaging tests to diagnose the cause of your joint pain.
Follow these instructions at home:
Managing pain, stiffness, and swelling
If directed, put ice on the painful area. Icing can help to relieve joint pain and swelling.
? Put ice in a plastic bag.
? Place a towel between your skin and the bag.
? Leave the ice on for 20 minutes, 23 times a day.
If directed, apply heat to the painful area as often as told by your health care provider. Heat can reduce the stiffness of your muscles and joints. Use the heat source that your health care provider recommends, such as a moist heat pack or a heating pad.
? Place a towel between your skin and the heat source.
? Leave the heat on for 2030 minutes.
? Remove the heat if your skin turns bright red. This is especially important if you are unable to feel pain, heat, or cold. You may have a greater risk of getting burned.
Move your fingers or toes below the painful joint often. You can avoid stiffness and lessen swelling by doing this.
If possible, raise (elevate) the painful joint above the level of your heart while you are sitting or lying down. To do this, try putting a few pillows under the painful joint.
Activity
Rest the painful joint for as long as directed. Do not do anything that causes or worsens pain.
Begin exercising or stretching the affected area, as told by your health care provider. Ask your health care provider what types of exercise are safe for you.
If you have an elastic bandage, sling, or splint:
Wear the supportive device as told by your health care provider. Remove it only as told by your health care provider.
Loosen the device if your fingers or toes below the joint tingle, become numb, or turn cold and blue.
Keep the device clean.
Ask your health care provider if you should remove the device before bathing. You may need to cover it with a watertight covering when you take a bath or a shower.
General instructions
Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco, such as cigarettes and e-cigarettes. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.
Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if:
You have pain that gets worse and does not get better with medicine.
Your joint pain does not improve within 3 days.
You have increased bruising or swelling.
You have a fever.
You lose 10 lb (4.5 kg) or more without trying.
Get help right away if:
You cannot move the joint.
Your fingers or toes tingle, become numb, or turn cold and blue.
You have a fever along with a joint that is red, warm, and swollen.
Summary
Joint pain (arthralgia) may be caused by many things.
Your health care provider may recommend that you take pain medicine or wear a supportive device like an elastic bandage, sling, or splint.
If your joint pain continues, you may need tests to diagnose the cause of your joint pain.
Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
